review.title: Learning Linguistic Biomarkers for Predicting Mild Cognitive Impairment using Compound Skip-grams
review.abstract: Predicting Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) is currently a challenge as existing diagnostic criteria rely on neuropsychological examinations. Automated Machine Learning (ML) models that are trained on verbal utterances of MCI patients can aid diagnosis. Using a combination of skip-gram features, our model learned several linguistic biomarkers to distinguish between 19 patients with MCI and 19 healthy control individuals from the DementiaBank language transcript clinical dataset. Results show that a model with compound of skip-grams has better AUC and could help ML prediction on small MCI data sample.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: MCI is typically diagnosed through neuropsychological examinations using a series of cognitive tests [1, 2]. Since MCI leads to deterioration in the cognitive abilities of nerve cells that control cognitive, linguistic and linguistic processes [4, 5], language impairments caused by verbal expressions may indicate signs of MCI [6, 7, 8]. In [9], on the other hand, complex syntactical characteristics were used to distinguish between 37 patients with MCI and 37 healthy control groups. Seven statistically significant linguistic features of "immediate logic memory" were combined with multiple test values to achieve 86.1% AUC. In contrast, we distinguished MCI patients using multiple skip diagrams alone [10]. The skip diagrams are able to represent the language space of MCI patients due to the lexical and synchronous errors that we frequently observe in their language.

sections.heading: 2 Learning linguistic skip-gram biomarkers
sections.text: In contrast to ordinary n-grams, word marks are skipped intermittently while n-grams are created. In the sentence "Take the Cookie Jar," for example, there are three conventional bigrams: "Take the Cookie Jar," "Take the Cookie Jar," and "Cookie Jar." We believe that such "Skip-grams" could capture unique linguistic biomarkers in verbal expressions. − For example, we used a combination of "Skip-grams" to effectively distinguish MCI patients from their healthy controls.
